title: State v. White
description: White pled guilty to six counts of threatening a public official and was sentenced to six five-year terms.  She now appeals asserting the trial court abused its discretion by failing to order a medical examination to determine her competency to stand trial based on her documented history of congenital brain damage and severe mental illness.

title: McCune v. Myrtle Beach Indoor Shooting Range, Inc.
description: Appellant brought an action for negligence and strict liability against Respondent for injuries sustained while she was participating in a paintball game.  Appellant appeals the grant of summary judgment in favor of Respondent.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Christine McCune,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Myrtle Beach Indoor Shooting Range, Inc., a/k/a Myrtle Beach Shooting Range, Inc. and Brass Eagle, Inc.,       
Defendants,
of whom Myrtle Beach Indoor Shooting Range, Inc., a/k/a Myrtle Beach Shooting Range, Inc. is,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3974
Heard March 8, 2005 â€“ Filed April 11, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jill Wright Fennel, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
John H. Tiller and Elizabeth Applegate Dieck, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Christine McCune brought an action for negligence and strict liability against the Myrtle Beach Indoor Shooting Range (the Range) for injuries sustained while she was participating in a paintball game.[1]Â  McCune appeals from the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to the Range.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The Range offers paintball games and allows participants to rent protective equipment, including face masks, provided by the Range.Â Â McCune participated in a paintball match with her husband and friends.Â  She utilized a mask provided by the Range.Â  Prior to being allowed to participate, McCune signed a general waiver.Â  The waiver released the Range from liability from all known or unknown dangers for any reason with the exception of gross negligence on the part of the Range.
During her play, the mask was loose and ill fitting.Â  She attempted to have the mask tightened or replaced on several occasions and an employee of the Range attempted to properly fit the mask for McCune.Â  While playing in a match, McCune caught the mask on the branch of a tree.Â  The tree was obscured from her field of vision by the top of the mask.Â  The mask was raised off her face because it was loose, and provided no protection against an incoming paintball pellet.Â  The pellet struck McCune in the eye, rendering her legally blind in the eye.
McCune brought suit, alleging causes of action for negligence and strict liability based on the failure of the mask to properly be fitted and protect her during play.Â  The Range filed an answer asserting the waiver released them from all liability as a result of the paintball striking McCune.Â  Additionally, it asserted McCuneâ€™s comparative negligence barred recovery.
Subsequently, the Range filed a motion for summary judgment, again alleging the waiver and McCuneâ€™s comparative negligence barred recovery.Â  The court granted the Rangeâ€™s motion, finding the waiver was sufficient to show McCune expressly assumed the risks associated with playing paintball.Â  Additionally, the court found her overwhelming comparative fault barred recovery.Â  The trial court subsequently denied McCuneâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court:Â  summary judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Cunningham ex rel. Grice v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 491, 575 S.E.2d 549, 552 (2003) (â€œSummary judgment is appropriate only if there is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non‑moving party below.â€Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  
DISCUSSION
 McCune maintains the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to the Range on the basis of the exculpatory language in the release of liability signed by McCune.Â  McCune asserts she did not anticipate the harm that was inflicted or the manner in which it occurred.Â  Additionally, she contends the failure of the equipment was unexpected and she could not have voluntarily assumed such a risk.Â  We disagree.
As an initial matter, we must determine whether this is a case involving express assumption or implied assumption of the risk.Â  Express assumption of the risk sounds in contract and occurs when the parties agree beforehand, â€œeither in writing or orally, that the plaintiff will relieve the defendant of his or her legal duty toward the plaintiff.â€Â  Davenport v. Cotton Hope Plantation Horizontal Prop. Regime, 333 S.C. 71, 79-80, 508 S.E.2d 565, 569-70 (1998).Â Â Â  
â€œExpress assumption of risk is contrasted with implied assumption of risk which arises when the plaintiff implicitly, rather than expressly, assumes known risks.Â  As noted above, implied assumption of risk is characterized as either primary or secondary.â€Â  Id. at 80-81, 508 S.E.2d at 570.Â  â€œ[P]rimary implied assumption of risk is but another way of stating the conclusion that a plaintiff has failed to establish a prima facie case [of negligence] by failing to establish that a duty exists.â€Â  Id. at 81, 508 S.E.2d at 570 (quoting Perez v. McConkey, 872 S.W.2d 897, 902 (Tenn. 1994)).Â  â€œSecondary implied assumption of risk, on the other hand, arises when the plaintiff knowingly encounters a risk created by the defendantâ€™s negligence.â€Â  Id. at 82, 508 S.E.2d at 571.
In the instant case, we are confronted with a defense based upon McCuneâ€™s express assumption of the risk.Â  She signed a release from liability prior to participating in the paintball match.Â  As acknowledged by Davenport, the courts of South Carolina have analyzed express assumption of the risk cases in terms of exculpatory contracts.Â  Id. at 80, 508 S.E.2d at 570.Â Â Â Â  
Exculpatory contracts, such as the one in this case, have previously been upheld by the courts of this state.Â  See Huckaby v. Confederate Motor Speedway, Inc., 276 S.C. 629, 630, 281 S.E.2d 223, 224 (1981) (finding plaintiffâ€™s action against speedway for injuries sustained during a race was barred by â€œwaiver and releaseâ€ voluntarily signed by plaintiff prior to entering the race track); Pride v. Southern Bell Tel. & Tel. Co., 244 S.C. 615, 619-22, 138 S.E.2d 155, 157-58 (1964) (holding it was not violative of public policy for telephone company to legally limit its liability by contract for negligence in the publication of a paid advertisement in the yellow pages of its telephone directory).Â  â€œHowever, notwithstanding the general acceptance of exculpatory contracts, â€˜[s]ince such provisions tend to induce a want of care, they are not favored by the law and will be strictly construed against the party relying thereon.â€™â€Â  Fisher v. Stevens, 355 S.C. 290, 295, 584 S.E.2d 149, 152 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting Pride, 244 S.C. at 619, 138 S.E.2d at 157).Â  This court has explained:

Common sense and good faith are the leading touchstones of the construction of a contract and contracts are to be so construed as to avoid an absurd result.Â  Where one construction would make a contract unusual or extraordinary and another, equally consistent, would make the contract reasonable, fair and just, the latter construction will prevail.Â Â  

Georgetown Mfg. & Warehouse Co. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Agric., 301 S.C. 514, 518, 392 S.E.2d 801, 804 (Ct. App. 1990) (citing C.A.N. Enters., Inc. v. South Carolina Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 373 S.E.2d 584 (1988)).
Contracts that seek to exculpate a party from liability for the partyâ€™s own negligence are not favored by the law.Â  Pride, 244 S.C. at 619, 138 S.E.2d at 157.Â  An exculpatory clause, our supreme court has held, is to be strictly construed against the party relying thereon.Â  Id.Â  An exculpatory clause will never be construed to exempt a party from liability for his own negligence â€œâ€˜in the absence of explicit language clearly indicating that such was the intent of the parties.â€™â€Â  South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co. v. Combustion Engâ€™g, Inc., 283 S.C. 182, 191, 322 S.E.2d 453, 458 (Ct. App. 1984) (quoting Hill v. Carolina Freight Carriers Corp., 71 S.E.2d 133, 137 (N.C. 1952)).
The release in the instant case explicitly and unambiguously limited the Rangeâ€™s liability.Â  Specifically, McCune signed the release, thereby acknowledging the following pertinent clauses:

1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The risk of injury from the activity and weaponry involved in paintball is significant, including the potential for permanent disability and death, and while particular protective equipment and personal discipline will minimize this risk, the risk of serious injury does exist;
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  I KNOWINGLY AND FREELY ASSUME ALL SUCH RISKS, both known and unknown, EVEN IF ARISING FROM THE NEGLIGENCE of those persons released from liability below, and assume full responsibility for my participation; and,
. . . 
4.Â Â Â Â Â Â  I, for myself and on behalf of my heirs . . . HEREBY RELEASE AND HOLD HARMLESS THE AMERICAN PAINTBALL LEAGUE (APL), THE APL CERTIFIED MEMBER FIELD, the owners and lessors of premises used to conduct the paintball activities, their officers, officials, agents, and/or employees (â€œReleaseesâ€), WITH RESPECT TO ANY AND ALL INJURY, DISABILITY, DEATH, or loss or damage to person or property, WHETHER CAUSED BY THE NEGLIGENCE OF THE RELEASEES OR OTHERWISE, except that which is the result of gross negligence and/or wanton misconduct.
. . . 
I HAVE READ THIS RELEASE OF LIABILITY AND ASSUMPTION OF RISK AGREEMENT, FULLY UNDERSTANDING ITS TERMS, UNDERSTAND THAT I HAVE GIVEN UP SUBSTANTIAL RIGHTS BY SIGNING IT, AND SIGN IT FREELY AND VOLUNTARILY WITHOUT ANY INDUCEMENT.

The agreement is then signed by McCune and dated the date of the incident.
The above agreement is sufficient to limit the liability of the Range to McCune.Â  The agreement was voluntarily signed and specifically stated:Â  (1) she assumed the risks, whether known or unknown; and (2) she released the Range from liability, even from injuries sustained because of the Rangeâ€™s own negligence.Â  It is clear McCune voluntarily entered into the release in exchange for being allowed to participate in the paintball match.Â  
Additionally, she expressly assumed the risk for all known and unknown risks while participating and cannot now complain because she did not fully appreciate the exact risk she faced.Â  â€œExcept where he expressly so agrees, a plaintiff does not assume a risk of harm arising from the defendantâ€™s conduct unless he then knows of the existence of the risk and appreciates its unreasonable character.â€Â  Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 496D (1965) (emphasis added).
We find the release entered into by the parties does not contravene public policy.Â  In Huckaby, the plaintiff signed a waiver similar to the one above, which was required before he could participate in a sanctioned automobile race.Â  He maintained his injuries were caused by the speedwayâ€™s faulty installation and maintenance of a guardrail.Â  Huckaby, 276 S.C. at 630, 281 S.E.2d at 223.Â  As was found in Huckaby, participation in a paintball match is voluntary.Â  â€œâ€˜If these agreements, voluntarily entered into, were not upheld, the effect would be to increase the liability of those organizing or sponsoring such events to such an extent that no one would be willing to undertake to sponsor a sporting event.Â  Clearly, this would not be in the public interest.â€™â€Â  Huckaby, 276 S.C. at 631, 281 S.E.2d at 224 (quoting Gore v. Tri-County Raceway, Inc., 407 F. Supp. 489, 492 (M.D. Ala. 1974)).Â  
Furthermore, we find the instant case to be distinguishable from this courtâ€™s decision in Fisher v. Stevens, 355 S.C. 290, 584 S.E.2d 149 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In Fisher, the plaintiff worked on a wrecker crew at the Speedway of South Carolina.Â  In order to work at the Speedway, Fisher was required to sign a release and waiver of liability.Â  During a race, the wrecker on which Fisher was working responded to a crash.Â  While the wrecker was moving towards one of the vehicles, Fisher, who was riding on the back of the wrecker, fell off and suffered severe head injuries.Â  Through a guardian, Fisher brought suit alleging negligence, gross negligence, and recklessness against the driver and the owner of the wrecker as well as the Speedway.Â  The defendants raised the Release as an affirmative defense.Â  All parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, alleging the Release acted as a complete bar to Fisherâ€™s claims.Â  The circuit court judge granted partial summary judgment to Fisher against the driver and the owner of the wrecker on the ground the Release, as a matter of law, did not bar Fisherâ€™s claims.Â  Additionally, the court denied summary judgment to the Speedway.Â  The court found an issue of material fact existed as to whether Fisher was an employee of the Speedway.Â Â  
On appeal, the driver and the owner of the wrecker argued the circuit court erred in finding the Release was inapplicable to them.Â  Specifically, they contended they were released from liability given the Release encompassed â€œVEHICLE OWNERS, DRIVERS, [and] . . . ANY PERSONS IN ANY RESTRICTED AREA.â€Â  Id. at 294, 584 S.E.2d at 151-52.Â  In analyzing this issue, we found the Release, an exculpatory contract, was ambiguous because the terms, â€œdriverâ€ and â€œvehicle ownerâ€ were â€œterms of art [which were] not used to identify any owner or driver of any vehicle.â€Â  Id. at 295, 584 S.E.2d at 152.Â Â  Additionally, we agreed with the circuit court that the phrase â€œANY PERSONS IN ANY RESTRICTED AREAâ€ did not relieve the driver and the owner of the wrecker of liability on the ground it was overly broad and, thus, in contravention of public policy.Â  Because the contract â€œdid not clearly inform Fisher he would be waiving all claims due to the [driverâ€™s and vehicle ownerâ€™s negligence], we held the driver and the vehicle owner could not be released from liability â€œbased on the broad â€˜catch-allâ€™ phrase.â€Â  Id. at 298, 584 S.E.2d at 153. 
In contrast, the release in the case at bar is neither ambiguous nor overbroad.Â  In fact, McCune in her deposition characterized the release as a â€œstandard waiver.â€Â  Although our research reveals no South Carolina case that deals specifically with a release for paintball, other jurisdictions have found similarly worded releases to be unambiguous.Â  See Taylor v. Hesser, 991 P.2d 35, 38 (Okla. Civ. App. 1998) (affirming grant of summary judgment to operators of paintball facility and shooter where plaintiff, who was injured during the paintball game, signed a release prior to participating); Kaltenbach v. Splatball, Inc., No. C7-99-235, 1999 WL 690191, at *2 (Minn. Ct. App. 1999) (finding paintball participant was precluded from recovering against owner of a paintball facility for injuries where participant signed a release of ownerâ€™s liability).
We would also note that unlike the release in Fisher, the release signed by McCune did not preclude recovery for a cause of action involving gross negligence.[2]Â  Thus, this opinion should not be construed as creating an indefensible position for all injuries sustained during inherently dangerous recreational activities.Â  Cf. Adams v. Roark, 686 S.W.2d 73, 75-76 (Tenn. 1985) (recognizing, in an action to recover for injuries sustained by a motorcyclist at a drag way, that an agreement to contract against liability for gross negligence is unenforceable); Murphy v. N. Am. River Runners, Inc., 412 S.E.2d 504, 510 (W.Va. 1991) (stating, in an action to recover for injuries sustained during a whitewater rafting accident, â€œa general clause in a pre-injury exculpatory agreement or anticipatory release purporting to exempt a defendant from all liability for any future loss or damage will not be construed to include the loss or damage resulting from the defendantâ€™s intentional or reckless misconduct or gross negligence, unless the circumstances clearly indicate that such was the plaintiffâ€™s intentionâ€).
Accordingly, we hold the trial court properly determined the release signed by McCune was sufficient to release the Range from all liability in this incident.Â  Therefore, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.[3]
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Brass Eagle, Inc., was also named in the action as the manufacturer of the mask McCune alleged was defective or in poor operating condition.Â  McCune and Brass Eagle settled the suit and Brass Eagle is not a party to this appeal.
[2]Â  Neither in her brief nor at oral argument did McCune assert that the Rangeâ€™s actions constituted gross negligence.Â  Instead, she acknowledged at oral argument that the Range operated with at least slight care by attempting to properly adjust the mask to McCune.Â  See ClyburnÂ  v. Sumter County Sch. Dist. No. 17, 317 S.C. 50, 53, 451 S.E.2d 885, 887 (1994)(â€œGross negligence is the intentional, conscious failure to do something which it is incumbent upon one to do or the doing of a thing intentionally that one ought not to do.â€); Faile v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 331-32, 566 S.E.2d 536, 544 (2002) (stating gross negligence â€œis the failure to exercise even the slightest careâ€).
[3] As we have affirmed the courtâ€™s decision based upon its analysis of the exculpatory contract, we need not determine whether McCuneâ€™s claim would also be barred because her negligence was greater than that of the Range.Â

title: Joyner v. Greenville Hotel Associates
description: Joyner, owner of a lot leased to a prior owner of the adjacent hotel to be used as a parking lot, argues the master in equity erred in granting summary judgment to the new hotel owners, and  finding the lease was not binding upon the subsequent purchasers of the hotel, because the lease provided it was binding upon subsequent purchasers and the deed to the hotel property described the property as including any right to the lease on the parking lot.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        C. Dan Joyner,       
        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Greenville Hotel Associates Limited Partnership,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 3975
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 11, 2005 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chris B. Roberts, of Greenville, for Appellant.
John A. Sowards, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  C. Dan Joyner appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Greenville Hotel Associates Limited Partnership (â€œGHALPâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The facts in the case are not disputed.Â  Joyner owned property adjacent to a hotel in Greenville, South Carolina.Â  He leased the property in 1971 to the Watkins, owners of the hotel, for use as an additional parking lot.Â  The lease was for a period of forty years, limited rent to $750 per month, and provided that the lease was binding upon the Watkinsâ€™ â€œrespective heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns.â€Â  The lease was amended in 1983, assigned to a subsequent owner of the hotel in 1995, and further assigned to a new owner, Stewart Mac Investments, LLC, in 1999.Â  All of the assignments of the lease agreement were recorded with the deed to the hotel property.Â  Stewart Mac Investments stopped paying rent in September 1999.Â Â  
Stewart Mac Investments defaulted on the mortgage for the hotel with GHALP, and a foreclosure action was instituted in June 2000.Â  The order granting the foreclosure noted that the property was â€œ[t]ogether with all right, title and interest of the Mortgagor in and to that certain Lease executed by and between C. Dan Joyner, Lessor, and Robert L. Watkins and Tamara A. Watkins, Lessees . . . .â€Â  GHALP purchased the hotel property, and the description of the property in the masterâ€™s deed included the above-quoted language that the property included the right to or interest in the lease with Joyner.[2]Â  The masterâ€™s deed also provided that the hotel property was purchased subject to a first mortgage with BB&T bank.Â  GHALP, however, never signed a lease assignment or lease agreement with Joyner.Â  GHALP never paid rent, or Stewart Mac Investmentsâ€™ arrears, to Joyner.Â Â  
Joyner brought an action against GHALP for breach of the lease agreement, breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, and for a declaratory judgment.Â  Joyner sought the unpaid rent, the arrearages allegedly assumed when GHALP obtained the property from Stewart Mac Investments, punitive damages for bad faith, and costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  GHALP answered, denying that it had assumed the lease when it obtained the property. 
Both parties moved for summary judgment.Â  Citing the dissent in the mortgage assignment case of Allgood v. Spearman, 125 S.C. 131, 118 S.E. 189 (1923) as valid law, GHALP argued that although it bought the property subject to the lease agreement: a separate assignment agreement with Joyner was never signed; the extra parking lot was never used; GHALP chose not to pay the rent; and GHALP could not be held personally responsible for a lease agreement to which it was not a party.Â  The master-in-equity found that although the deed to GHALP indicated that it was taking the property subject to the lease with Joyner, the language â€œin no way personally obligated [GHALP] on the Lease.â€Â  The master found that GHALP never signed anything or â€œexhibited any conduct such as occupying the premises, making lease payments, et cetera, that would indicate any basis for the Courtâ€™s imposing liability on it.â€Â  The master granted summary judgment to GHALP, denied summary judgment to Joyner, and Joynerâ€™s motion for reconsideration was denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate where there is no genuine issue of material fact and it is clear the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  If further inquiry into the facts is necessary to clarify application of the law, summary judgment is not appropriate.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  â€œSummary judgment should not be granted even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts if there is dispute as to the conclusion to be drawn from those facts.â€Â  Id.Â  The evidence and the inferences therefrom must be viewed in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Joyner argues the master erroneously relied upon the dissent in Allgood v. Spearman, 125 S.C. 131, 118 S.E. 189 (1923), and the â€œflawed arguments of counselâ€ in granting summary judgment to GHALP.Â  Joyner asserts that the lease agreement was binding upon GHALP because:Â  (1) the lease agreement provided it was binding upon the successors at interest; and (2) the property description in the GHALPâ€™s deed described the property as subject to the lease agreement.Â  Thus, Joyner argues, summary judgment should have been granted to Joyner, not GHALP.[3]
Although we can find no cases directly on point, GHALP cited Allgood as similar to the present case.Â  In Allgood, W.D. Spearman signed five promissory notes to E.F. Allgood for $5,203.87 each and secured by a mortgage on four tracts of land owned by Spearman.Â  Spearman later sold the land to R.B. Sheck, and then Spearman defaulted on the mortgage.Â  When Allgood attempted to foreclose on the property, Spearman asserted that Sheck assumed the obligation for the mortgage when he purchased the property.Â  The Allgood court affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s holding that Sheck assumed the debt when he purchased the land:Â  

â€œThere can be no doubt at this day that where the purchaser of land encumbered by a mortgage agrees to pay a particular sum as purchase money, and on the execution of the contract of purchase the amount of the mortgage is deducted from the consideration, and the land conveyed subject to the mortgage, that the purchaser is bound to pay the mortgage debt, whether he agreed to do so by express words or not.Â  This obligation results necessarily from the very nature of the transaction.Â  Having accepted the land subject to the mortgage, and kept back enough of the vendorâ€™s money to pay it, it is only common honesty that he should be required either to pay the mortgage or stand primarily liable for it.â€Â  

Allgood, 125 S.C. at 134, 118 S.E. at 189 (quoting Dargan v. McSween, 33 S.C. 338, 11 S.E. 1081 (1890)).Â  The dissenting judge in Allgood disagreed, citing treatises to the effect that: â€œâ€˜In the absence of a special agreement to assume the mortgage or words in the grant importing in some form that he assumes the payment of it, the purchaser is not personally liable for it.â€™â€Â  Id. at 138, 118 S.E. at 191 (quoting 1 Jones Mtg. (6th Ed.), 750).
The fact that GHALP bought the property subject to the lease is not disputed.Â  The only question is whether GHALP may be bound by that language in the lease and be held personally liable.Â  Although the majority opinion in Allgood appears to have implied an assumption of the debt by the purchaser, the present situation is clearly different from the one in Allgood. In Allgood the mortgage encumbered the purchased property and the purchaser deducted the mortgage balance from the purchase price.Â  The lease in question was not an encumbrance on the hotel property that GHALP purchased; the lease involved an adjacent parcel. Â 
The lease was a contract between the Watkins and Joyner, and later, between Joyner and subsequent owners who agreed to accept assignment of the lease.Â  The lease provided that it would be effective upon the lesseeâ€™s heirs and assigns.Â  However, GHALP did not expressly or impliedly assume the lease.Â  GHALP did not assume the lease by merely accepting the property subject to the contract between Joyner and the Watkinsâ€™ assignees.Â  â€œOne who accepts a conveyance subject to a lien or claim does not assume by such acceptance the obligation to discharge the lien or satisfy the claim.â€Â  77 Am.Jur.2d Vendor and Purchaser Â§ 406 (1997); see County of Albany v. Albany County Indus. Dev. Agency, 218 A.D.2d 435, 437 (N.Y. App. Div. 1996) (noting the well-settled rule that one who accepts a conveyance â€œsubject toâ€ a lien or claim does not assume by such acceptance the obligation to discharge the lien or satisfy the claim).Â  Absent an indication from GHALP that it agreed to be bound to the lease with Joyner, such as signing an assignment or exercising the duties and rights under the lease, GHALP has no legal obligation to Joyner.Â  Without a contract between the parties, expressed or implied, the relationship of landlord and tenant cannot exist.Â  Stewart-Jones Co. v. Shehan, 127 S.C. 451, 457, 121 S.E 374, 376 (1924). 
Even viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Joyner, nothing indicates GHALP separately agreed to be bound by the lease when it purchased the hotel property.Â  Accordingly, the master-in-equityâ€™s order granting summary judgment to GHALP is 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  
[2]Â  The master later determined that this language meant that GHALP took the property â€œsubject toâ€ the lease agreement.Â  This finding is unappealed.Â  
[3]Â  It is well-settled that the denial of a motion for summary judgment is not appealable.Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 168, 580 S.E.2d 440, 444 (2003).Â  Thus we decline to address Joynerâ€™s argument that the master erred by failing to grant him summary judgment.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Don Mackela, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        James Bentley d/b/a/ Lyman Auto Sales and Automotive Finance Corporation, Defendants,
        Of Whom, Automotive Finance Corporation is, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3976
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jennifer L. Queen, of Summerville, for Appellant.Â  
        David Charles Alford, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  In this action for conversion, the jury returned a verdict in favor of Don Mackela in the amount of $13,320.23 plus interest in actual damages and $50,000 in punitive damages against Automotive Finance Corporation (AFC).Â  AFC appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]

  FACTS
  In September 2001, Mackela owned a 1999 Dodge Grand Caravan.Â  Mackela sought to purchase a second vehicle from James Bentley, d/b/a Lyman Auto Sales.Â  Bentley allowed Mackela to park the Dodge on Bentleyâ€™s used car lot and agreed to assist Mackela in the sale of the vehicle.Â  Mackela retained title to the Dodge.Â  

Bentley unlocked and showed the Dodge to potential buyers, but was not authorized to negotiate its sale.Â  Although Bentley assumed he would receive some compensation if he sold the Dodge, Mackela and Bentley had no agreement regarding a price or a commission for Bentley.Â  Mackela periodically checked on the vehicle from September 2001 to January 2002 and never noticed any stickers or other papers indicating Bentley was advertising the car.Â  
AFC financed Bentleyâ€™s purchases of new vehicles as the floor planner of Lyman Auto Sales.Â  As part of the note, guaranty, and security agreement between Bentley and AFC, Bentley granted AFC a security interest in â€œ[a]ll now owned or hereafter acquired inventory.â€Â  Bentley defaulted on the AFC note.Â  AFC served a warrant of attachment on Bentley and attached forty-two vehicles from Bentleyâ€™s lot, including Mackelaâ€™s Dodge.Â  Mackela filed this action against AFC and James Bentley, d/b/a Lyman Auto Sales, alleging conversion and seeking actual and punitive damages.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
At trial, Mackela testified he called AFC to retrieve the Dodge after the attachment.Â  When Mackela explained his ownership, the AFC representative said AFC took the Dodge because â€œit was there.â€Â  The representative further told Mackela that AFC would not return the Dodge unless Mackela â€œpaid for it.â€Â  Mackela explained:Â  â€œIâ€™m already paying for it.â€Â  The representative replied:Â  â€œWell, youâ€™re going to have to pay for it again if you want to take it.Â  We wonâ€™t give you a release.â€Â  When the finance company that held Mackelaâ€™s note on the Dodge learned of the attachment, it refused further payments by Mackela and ultimately a judgment was entered against Mackela for approximately $13,000.Â  
Bentley testified at trial that only fifty percent of the vehicles taken by AFC were Lyman Auto Sales inventory.Â  The remaining vehicles, like Mackelaâ€™s Dodge, were not owned by Lyman Auto Sales.Â  Bentley explained that he attempted â€œon several occasionsâ€ to retrieve the vehicles from AFC but AFC refused to return the vehicles and the owners were forced to â€œget them back through different court orders.â€Â  
AFC moved for a directed verdict on the ground that AFC was acting within its legal rights as to its collateral when it took control of Mackelaâ€™s vehicle.Â  The trial court denied AFCâ€™s motion.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Bentley and against AFC.Â  The jury awarded Mackela actual damages of $13,320.23 plus interest and $50,000 in punitive damages.[2]Â  The trial court denied AFCâ€™s post-trial motion for new trial or judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  AFC appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS

On appeal from the denial of a motion for directed verdict, the appellate court may reverse only if no evidence supports the circuit court’s ruling. Steinke v. South Carolina Dep’t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999). Credibility issues and conflicts in testimony are for the jury. Garrett v. Locke, 309 S.C. 94, 99, 419 S.E.2d 842, 845 (Ct. App. 1992).
I.Â  Conversion 
AFC argues the trial court erred in denying its motion for a directed verdict on Mackelaâ€™s conversion claim and its post-trial motion for new trial or judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  We disagree.
A plaintiff claiming conversion may prevail based upon a showing of unauthorized detention of property, after demand.Â  The plaintiff must show either title or right to possession of the property at the time of conversion.Â  Oxford Fin. Cos. v. Burgess, 303 S.C. 534, 539, 402 S.E.2d 480, 482 (1991).Â  A plaintiffâ€™s claim for conversion fails where the defendant proves a legal right to the property.Â  Kirby v. Horne Motor Co., 295 S.C. 7, 11, 366 S.E.2d 259, 261-62 (Ct. App. 1988).
AFC asserts it had a legal right to Mackelaâ€™s vehicle because of a valid security interest in Bentleyâ€™s inventory.Â  Specifically, AFC alleges Mackelaâ€™s vehicle was collateral under the AFC-Bentley security agreement because the vehicle was on Bentleyâ€™s lot as a consignment item.Â  We disagree.Â  
Under section 36-9-102 of the South Carolina Code, â€œcollateralâ€ includes â€œgoods that are the subject of a consignment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-9-102(12)(C) (2003).Â  The Code defines â€œconsignmentâ€ as â€œa transaction, regardless of its form, in which a person delivers goods to a merchant for the purpose of sale.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-9-102(20) (2003).Â  However, goods that are â€œconsumer goods immediately before deliveryâ€ are specifically excluded from the statutory definition of consignment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-9-102(20)(C) (2003).Â  â€œConsumer goodsâ€ are defined as â€œgoods that are used or bought for use primarily for personal, family, or household purposes.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-9-102(23) (2003).Â  
Mackela testified he purchased the Dodge for his personal use, including the transportation of his wife to cancer treatments.Â  We find the Dodge thus meets the statutory definition of a consumer good.Â  Because the Dodge was a consumer good, it is excluded from the statutory definition of a consignment and AFCâ€™s argument that it was collateral as a consignment fails.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-9-102(20) (2003).Â  We find ample evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s denial of AFCâ€™s directed verdict motion and post-trial motion for new trial or judgment notwithstanding the verdict.
II.Â  Punitive Damages
Relying exclusively on Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991), AFC argues the trial court erred in affirming the juryâ€™s award of punitive damages.Â  We disagree.
Punitive damages are recoverable in conversion cases if the defendantâ€™s acts have been willful, reckless, and/or committed with conscious indifference to the rights of others.Â  Oxford, 303 S.C. at 539, 402 S.E.2d at 482.Â  The amount of damages, actual or punitive, remains largely within the discretion of the jury, as reviewed by the circuit court.Â  Gamble, 305 S.C. at 112, 406 S.E.2d at 355.Â  Only when the circuit courtâ€™s discretion is abused, amounting to an error of law, does it become the duty of the appellate court to set aside the award.Â  Id.[3]
The South Carolina Supreme Court enumerated eight factors to consider in determining whether a juryâ€™s award of punitive damages is proper:Â  (1) the defendantâ€™s degree of culpability; (2) the duration of the conduct; (3) the defendantâ€™s awareness or concealment; (4) the existence of similar past conduct; (5) the likelihood the award will deter the defendant or others from like conduct; (6) whether the award is reasonably related to the harm likely to result from such conduct; (7) the defendantâ€™s ability to pay; and finally, (8) â€œother factorsâ€ deemed appropriate.Â  Gamble, 305 S.C. at 111-12, 406 S.E.2d at 354.Â  
In its order, the trial court specifically addressed each of the Gamble factors, finding AFCâ€™s conduct in this matter warranted the award of punitive damages.Â  AFC admitted at trial that at the time it executed the writ of attachment, none of the vehicles on Bentleyâ€™s lot were listed in the floor plan agreement.Â  AFC ultimately returned numerous of the vehicles seized.Â  The actions of AFC deprived Mackela of the use of his vehicle for eighteen months.Â  AFC had other suits filed against it alleging similar conduct.Â  The punitive damages award is just over three times the actual damages and is less than the $80,000 AFC claimed due from its account with Bentley.Â  
We find the trial court expressly considered the Gamble factors in its review of the punitive damages award and made appropriate findings of fact as to each factor.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the order on appeal is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] On the Form 4 Order, the award is stated as $13,325.23.Â  However, the trial courtâ€™s written order calculating the total award including interest cites the award as $13,320.23. 
[3] AFC neither requests us to nor suggests that we must conduct a de novo review of the award of punitive damages in this case pursuant to Cooper Indus., Inc. v. Leatherman Tool Group, Inc., 532 U.S. 424 (2001) and State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Campbell, 538 U.S. 408 (2003).Â  We therefore limit our review to the trial courtâ€™s Gamble review.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Ex Parte:  United Services Automobile Association Respondent,
        In Re:  Becky Todd Smith and Barry Smith, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Tracy Lee Moore and Ola A. Moore, Respondents.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3977
Heard January 10, 2005 â€“ Filed April 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Steven M. Krause and Daniel L. Draisen, both of Anderson, for Appellants.
        David L. Moore, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: This appeal stems from a tort action Becky Todd Smith brought against Tracy Lee Moore pursuant to a car accident between the two parties.Â  United Services Automobile Association (USAA), the insurance carrier for Becky Todd Smith and Barry Smith, moved to be dismissed from the case, arguing that Becky Todd Smith, who was listed as an â€œoperatorâ€ on the declarations page but was not the named insured, could not stack underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage.Â  The trial court granted USAAâ€™s motion.Â  We affirm.
FACTS

The automobile accident that prompted this litigation occurred in September of 2000 in Oconee County.Â  A vehicle owned by Ola A. Moore and operated by Tracey Lee Moore turned left in front of a vehicle operated by Becky Todd Smith.Â Â  The Smiths brought an action against the Moores for injuries and damages resulting from the accident.Â  
Tracey Lee Mooreâ€™s liability is undisputed.Â Â  Her vehicle was insured by Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, which tendered the liability limits on its policy and is not a subject of this appeal.[1]Â Â  The vehicle Becky Todd Smith was driving was insured by USAA under a policy issued to Betty Gillispie Washnok, who owned the vehicle.Â  Smith was driving the vehicle with Washnokâ€™s permission.Â Â  
Washnok treated Smith as if she were her daughter and served as her guardian, though it is unclear whether a legal adoption ever took place.Â  At the time of the accident, however, Smith no longer resided with Washnok.Â  
Washnok owned two vehicles, both of which were insured through USAA.Â  Although Washnok was the named insured, Smith was listed as an â€œoperator.â€Â Â  The term â€œoperatorâ€ is not defined in the policy.Â  
Because Smith was driving the vehicle with Washnokâ€™s permission, she was entitled to UIM coverage as a permissive user.Â Â  USAA paid one level of UIM benefits under a covenant not to execute.Â  Smithâ€™s injuries were extensive, however, and the damages she incurred exceeded the first level of UIM benefits.Â  Thus, Smith sought to stack UIM coverage from Washnokâ€™s other vehicle.Â Â  
USAA moved to be dismissed from the case, arguing that Smith was not a Class I insured, and therefore was not entitled to stack UIM coverage.Â  After a hearing, the trial court granted USAAâ€™s motion. Â This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW

Rule 41(b), SCRCP, allows a defendant to move for dismissal in cases tried without a jury on the ground that â€œupon the facts and the law the plaintiff has shown no right to relief.â€Â  See Silvester v. Spring Valley Country Club, 344 S.C. 280, 284, 543 S.E.2d 563, 565 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Because a dismissal under these circumstances has the same effect as summary judgment, the standard for summary judgment applies.Â  Id. at 284-85, 543 S.E.2d at 566. 
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear there is no genuine issue of material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Id. at 285, 543 S.E.2d at 566.Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, this court must view all evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. 
LAW/ANALYSIS

At issue in this case is whether an insured who is listed on the policy as an â€œoperatorâ€ can stack UIM coverage.Â  In South Carolina, only Class I insureds can stack coverage.Â  Concrete Servs., Inc. v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 331 S.C. 506, 509, 498 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1998).Â  Class I insureds include the named insured and his or her spouse and relatives residing in the same household.Â  Id.Â  Class II insureds are those using the insured vehicle with permission of the named insured and guests.Â  Id.Â  
Smith was not the named insured or the named insuredâ€™s spouse; nor does she does qualify as a resident relative.Â  Although the pleadings refer to Smith as Washnokâ€™s adopted daughter, it is undisputed that Smith did not reside in the same household as Washnok at the time of the accident.
The Smithsâ€™ argument is essentially that USAAâ€™s inclusion of Smith as an â€œoperatorâ€ on the declarations page of the policy created an ambiguity as to whether she was a named insured and such an ambiguity should be resolved in favor of coverage.Â  No cases in South Carolina have addressed this question to date.
Courts in some states have found in favor of coverage in similar situations.Â  The leading case is Lehrhoff v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 638 A.2d 889 (N.J. Super. Ct. App. Div. 1994).Â  In Lehrhoff, the court found that the insured was entitled to uninsured motorist coverage because of his inclusion on the declarations page as a driver of the insured vehicle.Â  Id. at 892.Â  Rhode Island followed suit, concluding that â€œthe listing of driversâ€™ names on the declarations page, without more, gives rise to an ambiguity in respect to whether such drivers are in fact covered under the terms of a policy.â€Â  Mallane v. Holyoke Mut. Ins. Co., 658 A.2d 18, 20 (R.I. 1995). 
These cases, however, relied on the doctrine of reasonable expectations.Â  See Lehrhoff, 638 A.2d at 892 (â€œ[W]e are . . . convinced that reasonable expectations of coverage raised by the declaration page cannot be contradicted by the policyâ€™s boilerplate . . . .â€); Mallane, 658 A.2d at 21 (quoting the above language from Lehrhoff in reliance).Â  The doctrine of reasonable expectations, which is essentially that the objectively reasonable expectations of insureds as to coverage will be honored even though a careful review of the terms of the policy would have shown otherwise, has been rejected in South Carolina.Â  Allstate Ins. Co. v. Mangum, 299 S.C. 226, 231-32, 383 S.E.2d 464, 466-67 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  Moreover, the Mallane court recognized that its holding was a minority position.Â  Mallane, 658 A.2d at 21.Â  
Additionally, neither Lehrhoff nor Mallane dealt with stacking.Â  The issue in both cases was whether boilerplate provisions in the policy could be used to defeat uninsured motorist coverage provided under the policy.Â  Lehrhoff, 638 A.2d at 889, 892; Mallane, 658 A.2d at 20.Â  In the case sub judice, USAA has already paid the UIM coverage for the car involved in the accident, and the issue is whether Smith is entitled to additional UIM coverage from Washnokâ€™s second car.
The majority view is that listing a driver on the declarations page of an insurance policy does not make that person a named insured.Â  In Georgia Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Wilkerson, 549 S.E.2d 740 (Ga. Ct. App. 2001), the Georgia Court of Appeals held that although neither â€œnamed insuredâ€ nor â€œdriverâ€ were defined in the insurance policy, the policy was not ambiguous.Â  Id. at 742.Â  Therefore, the person listed as a driver in the insurance policy was not allowed to stack coverage.Â  Likewise, the North Carolina Court of Appeals has held that â€œdriverâ€ and â€œnamed insuredâ€ are not synonymous because such a construction would expand the term â€œnamed insuredâ€ beyond its common sense meaning.Â  Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Williams, 472 S.E.2d 220, 222 (N.C. App. 1996).Â  The court went on to hold that a â€œdriverâ€ was not a Class I insured.Â  Id.Â  Other courts have agreed.Â  See Millspaugh v. Ross, 645 N.E.2d 14 (Ind. Ct. App. 1994) (holding that being named a â€œprincipal driverâ€ does not create an ambiguity and does not transform one into a named insured); Kitmirides v. Middlesex Mut. Assurance Co., 783 A.2d 1079 (Conn. App. Ct. 2001) (rejecting Lehrhoff and Mallane and finding no ambiguity, and ultimately holding that a listed driver is not a named insured); Fed. Kemper Ins. Co. v. Schneider, 474 A.2d 224 (Md. Ct. Spec. App. 1984) (holding that adding a driver to a policy does not make him a named insured); see also 7 Couch on Insurance Â§ 110:1 (â€œ[O]ne listed in the policy, but only in the status of a driver of a vehicle, is not a named insured despite the fact that such personâ€™s name was physically in the policy.â€). 
Furthermore, even though â€œoperatorâ€ is not defined in the policy, the policy is not ambiguous.Â  Where a term is not defined in a policy, it is to be â€œdefined according to the usual understanding of the termâ€™s significance to the ordinary person.â€Â  Mfrs. and Merchants Mut. Ins. Co. v. Harvey, 330 S.C. 152, 158, 498 S.E.2d 222, 225 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The term â€œoperatorâ€ has been construed somewhat more expansively than â€œdriverâ€ in this state, but has not been contemplated to extend beyond mere use of the vehicle.Â  State v. Graves, 269 S.C. 356, 237 S.E.2d 584 (1977) (explaining that the term â€œoperatorâ€ is broader than the term â€œdriverâ€ because it includes acts such as starting the engine or â€œmanipulating the mechanical or electrical agencies of a vehicleâ€).Â  In addition, the policy defines â€œyouâ€ and â€œyourâ€ as â€œthe â€˜named insuredâ€™ shown in the declarations.â€Â Â  The only person listed in the â€œNamed Insuredâ€ box on the declarations page was Washnok.Â  Thus, we see no ambiguity.
We therefore adopt the majority view and hold that listing an individual as an operator on the declarations page of an insurance policy does not make that individual a named insured.Â  Because Smith was not the named insured (or the named insuredâ€™s spouse or resident relative), but was only using the vehicle with Washnokâ€™s permission, she is a Class II insured, and as such, she is not entitled to stack coverage.Â  
Based on the foregoing, the order of the trial judge is hereby
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Litigation remains pending on the issue of excess liability coverage available to the Moores in a separate declaratory judgment action.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kenneth Roach, Appellant.
        
      
    
  

__________
Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
__________
Opinion No. 3978
Heard March 9, 2005 â€“ Filed April 18, 2005
__________
AFFIRMED
__________

  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport,Â  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Kenneth Roach appeals from his convictions for multiple drug offenses, arguing the trial court erred (1) by admitting hearsay in violation of the Confrontation Clause and (2) by admitting an in-court identification, which was based on a single photograph lineup, without making a determination as to the reliability of the identification.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS

On May 17, 2001, police were involved in a narcotics investigation and went to Roachâ€™s home to execute a search warrant for possession and distribution of crack cocaine.Â  Prior to executing the warrant, a confidential informant, who had prior drug charges himself, agreed to assist the police.Â  He testified that with twenty dollars the police had given him, he went to Roachâ€™s home and purchased drugs directly from Roach.Â  
Officers had Roachâ€™s home under surveillance at the time of the confidential informantâ€™s purchase.Â  When the officers approached the door of Roachâ€™s home to execute the warrant, they found it had been barricaded.Â  The officers knocked, and after receiving no response, they removed the door and entered the home.Â  The officers observed several people inside, including Roach, who ran into the bathroom and flushed the toilet.Â  Officers recovered crack cocaine from a plastic bag in the bathroom sink.Â  
Â In March 2002, Roach was indicted by the York County grand jury for one count of possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute, one count of possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute within the proximity of a public school, two counts of distribution of crack cocaine, and one count of distribution within the proximity of a public school.Â  Roach was convicted on all charges and sentenced to an aggregate term of thirty years in prison.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Violation of Confrontation Clause
Roach alleges his right to confront witnesses was violated when the trial court permitted an officer to testify about third parties going to Roachâ€™s home to purchase crack.Â  We agree, but find this error was harmless. 
According to in camera testimony proffered by the State, several people came to the door of Roachâ€™s home while officers executed the search warrant, and one of the executing officers sold imitation crack to the visitors.Â  Defense counsel objected on the basis of relevance and also argued the testimony violated Roachâ€™s rights pursuant to the Confrontation Clause because he was unable to cross-examine the individuals who purchased the imitation crack. The State argued that there was a logical inference that Roach was holding drugs for delivery and that this was probative of the intent of what he was doing at the house. Â The trial court overruled the objection, and the Stateâ€™s witness testified before the jury as follows:Â  

  
    Q. 
    You said you were stationed by the door?
  
  
    A.
    Yes, sir, I was.
  
  
    Q.
    While you were by the door what happened?
  
  
    A.   
    Several people came to the door and presented me with some money, two particular cases, one presented with a $10 [sic] with an intent to buy crack.
  
  
    Q.
    Don’t tell us what they were thinking because we don’t know.  People offered you money?
  
  
    A.
    Yes, sir.
  
  
    Q.
    And you were in plain clothes?
  
  
    A.
    Yes, sir.
  
  
    Q.
    And what did you offer them in exchange for the money?
  
  
    A.
    Imitation crack. 
  

â€œThe Sixth Amendment guarantees a criminal defendant the right â€˜to be confronted with the witnesses against him.â€™â€Â  State v. Dinkins, 339 S.C. 597, 601, 529 S.E.2d 557, 559 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting U.S. Const. amend. VI).Â  The right of confrontation is essential to a fair trial because it promotes reliability and insures that convictions will not result from testimony of individuals who cannot be challenged at trial.Â  Id.Â Â  Although the confrontation clause is not identical to the hearsay rule, when the State offers hearsay evidence in a criminal case, the accusedâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront accusers is directly implicated.Â  See Idaho v. Wright, 497 U.S. 805 (1990); Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Father et al., 317 S.C. 283, 454 S.E.2d 307 (1995).Â  
While the law requires confrontation with adverse witnesses, several exceptions have been recognized. See Danny R. Collins, South Carolina Evidence Â§ 16.11 (2d ed. 2000). Traditionally, â€œ[c]onfrontation [was] not always required in particular proceedings that serve[d] limited functions, for well-recognized hearsay exceptions, or for evidence that [had] other significant indicia of reliability.â€Â  Id.Â Â  In its most recent analysis of the Confrontation Clause, the United States Supreme Court modified the long-standing exemption for evidence bearing adequate â€œindicia of reliability.â€Â  Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 124 S.Ct. 1354 (2004).Â Â  In Crawford, the Supreme Court established a new rule which bars out-of-court statements by a witness that are testimonial in nature unless the witness is unavailable and the defendant had a prior opportunity to cross-examine the witness.Â  Id. at ___, 124 S.Ct. at 1374.Â  However, where the out-of-court statement is not testimonial in nature, the â€œindicia of reliabilityâ€ test remains.Â  Id. [1] 
Â â€œHearsay is an out of court statement, offered in court to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  State v. Townsend, 321 S.C. 55, 467 S.E.2d 138 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  A â€œstatementâ€ as defined by Rule 801(a), SCRE, includes â€œnonverbal conduct of a person, if it is intended by the person as an assertion.â€Â  See also id., 321 S.C. at 59, 467 S.E.2d at 141 (finding the gesture of pointing to be an assertion).
In this case, the officer testified about individuals â€œofferingâ€ him money in exchange for drugs.Â  While the officer did not specifically testify as to what these individuals said to him, if anything, he did testify that the individuals communicated to him, in some way, their desire to purchase drugs.Â Â  The State offered this evidence to prove that Roach was running a â€œcrack houseâ€ that people visited with the intent to purchase drugs.Â  Thus, the officerâ€™s testimony regarding the transaction, even if it was communicated nonverbally, falls under the definition of hearsay as it was an out-of-court statement, offered in court to prove the truth of the matter asserted.Â  The out-of-court statements were not testimonial in nature because they were made by individuals who had no idea they were actually attempting to buy drugs from a police officer.Â  See State v. Staten, Op. No. 3955 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 7, 2005 Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 12 at 31) (explaining that in other jurisdictions, statements made to acquaintances without an intention for use at trial have consistently been labeled as non-testimonial).Â  As non-testimonial hearsay statements, they would be admissible if they fell within a well-recognized hearsay exception or bore other significant indicia of reliability, which they do not. Accordingly, the trial court erred in allowing the testimony into evidence.
However, â€œviolation of the confrontation clause is not per se reversible but is subject to a harmless error analysis.â€Â  State v. Clark, 315 S.C. 478, 481, 445 S.E.2d 633, 634 (1994).Â  â€œAn error is harmless when it â€˜could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€™â€ State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (quoting State v. Key, 256 S.C. 90, 180 S.E.2d 888 (1971)).Â Â Â  
In this case, a confidential informant testified that he had purchased drugs from Roach immediately prior to the officersâ€™ execution of their search warrant.Â  Another witness also testified that she cut crack cocaine with Roach just moments before the officers burst into Roachâ€™s home.Â  Numerous people were in the home, all of whom fled when the officers came into the home.Â  Furthermore, Roach ran to the bathroom and flushed the toilet when officers entered his home, and crack cocaine was found in the sink of that bathroom.Â  In light of this overwhelming evidence against Roach, we do not believe the hearsay testimony regarding an officerâ€™s sale of imitation crack could have reasonably affected the result of the trial.
II.Â Â Â Â  Admission of Identification
Roach next argues the trial court erred by allowing an in-court identification, which was based on a single person lineup, without making a determination as to the reliability of the identification.Â  We disagree.
At Roachâ€™s trial, a confidential informant testified in camera that he told police he could purchase crack from 523 East White Street, the address of Roachâ€™s home.Â  The informant, however, did not know the name of the seller.Â  Police showed him a photograph of Roach, and the informant identified him as the person from whom he had purchased crack many times during a four-month period.Â  
Defense counsel argued the informant should not be allowed to identify Roach in court because the one photograph lineup was unduly suggestive.Â  Counsel further argued the informantâ€™s identification was unreliable because he was smoking crack and was going to various other places to purchase crack.Â  The trial judge agreed the lineup was suggestive, but ultimately allowed the identification to be admitted, explaining:

  Even though [a one photograph lineup] would be suggestive on its face . . . I find that the identification is not to be excluded because I donâ€™t believe there is a substantial risk of misidentification.Â  The witness testified that he viewed this person, perhaps, he didnâ€™t know his name, maybe the photograph connected the name, and I donâ€™t find any problem with that, but he certainly has the ability based on his previous purchases and contact with [Roach] or the person he identified as [Roach] and the person he identified as the person from whom he purchased.Â  I find that his in court identification will be allowed.Â  

 After making that finding, the trial judge went on to explain:

  Iâ€™ll certainly charge the jury that they are to take into consideration whatever factors they need to in regard to determining whether or not that is a reliable [identification].Â  [T]hatâ€™s not what the court is deciding, Iâ€™m not deciding whether itâ€™s reliable, Iâ€™m deciding whether itâ€™s admissible. 

The United States Supreme Court has developed a two-prong inquiry to determine the admissibility of an out-of-court identification.Â  Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188, 198-99 (1972).Â  First, the trial judge must ascertain whether the identification process was unduly suggestive.Â  State v. Moore, 343 S.C. 282, 287, 540 S.E.2d 445, 447 (2000).Â  Next, the trial judge must decide whether the out-of-court identification was nevertheless so reliable that no substantial likelihood of misidentification existed.Â  Id.Â  â€œSingle person show-ups are disfavored because they are suggestive by their nature.â€Â  State v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 251, 525 S.E.2d 535, 541 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œHowever, an identification may be reliable under the totality of the circumstances even when a suggestive procedure has been used.â€Â  State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 78, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000).
Roach argues the trial judgeâ€™s ruling should be reversed because the judge explicitly refused to evaluate the reliability of the identification.Â  We disagree.Â  As is clear from the trial judgeâ€™s ruling excerpted above, he considered the reliability of the identification and found there was no substantial risk for misidentification.Â  Although he went on to say, â€œIâ€™m not deciding whether itâ€™s reliable, Iâ€™m deciding whether itâ€™s admissible,â€ this statement must be taken in context.Â  This statement was made as the trial judge explained how he would charge the jury.Â  Ultimately, it was the juryâ€™s responsibility, as the sole arbiter of the facts, to determine whether the in-court identification was credible.Â  Thus, the trial judge was merely explaining that despite the identificationâ€™s admissibility, it would be in the juryâ€™s hands to determine whether to rely on the identification when determining Roachâ€™s guilt.Â  We thus find no error.
Accordingly, Roachâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The Supreme Court declined to â€œspell out a comprehensive definition of â€˜testimonial,â€™â€ but noted that the term â€œapplies at a minimum to prior testimony at a preliminary hearing, before a grand jury, or at a former trial; and to police interrogations.â€Â  Crawford, 541 U.S. ___, 124 S.Ct. at 1367.Â  For a comprehensive review of testimonial and non-testimonial hearsay, see State v. Staten, Op. No. 3955 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 7, 2005 Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 12 at 22).
