THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        
        Nataliya Holler, Respondent,
        
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        William Holler, Appellant.
          
        
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3979
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed April 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        William Holler, of Rock Hill, Pro Se, for Appellant.
        David Bradley Jordan, of Rock Hill and Harold A. Oberman, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â William Holler (Husband) appeals from the family courtâ€™s determination that a premarital agreement signed by Nataliya[1] Holler (Wife) is not enforceable.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Wife is originally from Ukraine.Â  She was educated in Ukraine and taught college students in that country.Â  English is not Wifeâ€™s first language.Â  After seeing Husbandâ€™s picture in â€œa feminine magazine,â€ Wife wrote a letter to him in English and included her phone number.Â  Thereafter, Husband and Wife talked on the phone for â€œ[a]bout a year.â€Â  Their conversations were in English.Â  During this time, Husband visited Wife in Ukraine.
On September 5, 1997, Wife traveled to the United States to marry Husband.Â  At the time of her arrival, Wifeâ€™s English was â€œreally poor.â€Â  Husband disputed Wifeâ€™s inability to speak English, claiming she spoke â€œ[v]ery well.â€Â  Upon completing an English course, Wife received a certificate from Central Piedmont College in May of 1998.
In October or early November 1997, Wife became pregnant with Husbandâ€™s child.Â  Wifeâ€™s visa was scheduled to expire on December 4, 1997, and she would have to return to Ukraine unless she married Husband.Â  Wife came to the United States without money and relied upon Husband to provide support.
Wife admitted that, while she was still in Ukraine, Husband told her about the premarital agreement.Â  However, Wife believed she â€œneeded to sign some papers under the law of South Carolina before we g[o]t married.â€Â  Wife claimed: â€œ[Husband] faxed me some documents for American Embassy, and one page was he told me that we needâ€”when you get to United States we have to sign that agreement before we get married because this is under [the] law of South Carolina.â€Â  Husband delivered the premarital agreement to Wife sometime before the marriage.Â  Husband first stated he faxed it to her five or six months before she arrived in the United States.Â  Husband maintained he handed her a copy to sign within a week after she arrived.Â  Yet, Wife declared Husband gave her a copy of the premarital agreement only two weeks before she signed it. 
Prior to signing the premarital agreement, Wife attempted to translate a portion of the agreement from English into Russian, but was unable to complete the translation.Â  â€œBecause it was too hard,â€ Wife became frustrated with the translation and quit.Â  Wife had eleven pages of translation before she determined the effort was futile.Â  Wife professed the agreement â€œhad specific language which [she did not] understand even in Russian.â€Â  Wife never retained counsel because she had no money to pay someone to review the agreement.
Wife signed the agreement on November 25, 1997.Â  The parties were married on December 1, 1997, merely three days before Wifeâ€™s visa was set to expire.
Husband and Wife separated on February 13, 2000.Â  Wife brought this action seeking a divorce, custody of the partiesâ€™ child, child support, equitable distribution of marital property, and alimony.Â  Husband answered and counterclaimed.Â  Subsequently, he filed a motion to dismiss the claims for alimony and equitable distribution asserting the premarital agreement controlled.Â  After a hearing, the family court denied the motion to dismiss.Â  The court ruled the premarital agreement was invalid and unenforceable because it was signed under duress and was unconscionable.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 569 S.E.2d 367 (2002); Lanier v. Lanier, Op. No. 3966 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 21, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 14 at 74); Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, Op. No. 3932 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 31, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 48).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 522 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 608 S.E.2d 147 (Ct. App. 2005); Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 526 S.E.2d 241 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband raises numerous issues regarding the findings of fact made by the family court.Â  In essence, the attack by Husband on the order of the family court involves two issues: (1) whether the court erred in finding the premarital agreement invalid and unenforceable; and (2) whether the family court had jurisdiction to determine the validity of the premarital agreement.
I.Â  JURISDICTION OF FAMILY COURT

Husband argues the family court was without jurisdiction to determine the validity of the premarital agreement.Â  He maintains Wife should have brought her action in the circuit court because the premarital agreement barred Wife from receiving alimony and designated the partiesâ€™ respective property as nonmarital.Â  We disagree.
The jurisdiction of the family court is determined by section 20-7-420 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004).Â  Section 20-7-420(2) provides:Â  

  The family court shall have exclusive jurisdiction:
  
    . . . .
    (2) To hear and determine actions:
    For divorce a vinculo matrimonii, separate support and maintenance, legal separation, and in other marital litigation between the parties, and for settlement of all legal and equitable rights of the parties in the actions in and to the real and personal property of the marriage and attorneyâ€™s fees, if requested by either party in the pleadings.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(2) (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  South Carolina Code section 20-3-130(G) states:

  (G) The Family Court may review and approve all agreements which bear on the issue of alimony or separate maintenance and support, whether brought before the court in actions for divorce from the bonds of matrimony, separate maintenance and support actions, or in actions to approve agreement where the parties are living separate and apart.Â  The failure to seek a divorce, separate maintenance, or a legal separation does not deprive the court of its authority and jurisdiction to approve and enforce the agreements.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(G) (Supp. 2004).
This court and the South Carolina Supreme Court have allowed appeals from the family court involving a premarital agreement without raising an issue of jurisdiction.Â  See, e.g., Hardee v. Hardee, 355 S.C. 382, 585 S.E.2d 501 (2003); Bowen v. Bowen, 352 S.C. 494, 575 S.E.2d 553 (2003); Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 543 S.E.2d 224 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In Gilley v. Gilley, 327 S.C. 8, 488 S.E.2d 310 (1997), the validity of the prenuptial agreement of the parties was not challenged.Â  The Gilley court analyzed the status of the property, i.e., marital or nonmarital in the context of the prenuptial agreement.Â  The court expounded:

  [H]usband asked the family court for an order of separate maintenance requiring the parties to live separate and apart, equitable distribution of the marital home and other personal property, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court dismissed husbandâ€™s action finding it did not belong in family court since the prenuptial agreement provides that neither party can claim alimony or separate maintenance.Â  Further, the family court dismissed the action because the prenuptial agreement provided that property acquired by the parties during the marriage or owned at the time of the marriage would not be the subject of any claims for equitable apportionment.Â  The family court ruled that any claims arising from property or investments must be asserted in circuit court.Â  We agree.
  The family court has exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine actions for separate support and maintenance, legal separation, other marital litigation between the parties, and for settlement of all legal and equitable rights of the parties in the actions related to the real and personal property of the marriage.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(2) (Supp. 1995).Â  Property excluded by written contract or antenuptial agreement of the parties is excluded from marital property and is considered nonmarital property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 1995).Â  The family court does not have authority to apportion nonmarital property.Â  Id.

Gilley, 327 S.C. at 11, 488 S.E.2d at 312.Â  Property excluded from the marital estate by written contract or premarital agreement of the parties is considered nonmarital property over which the family court has no jurisdiction.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004) (noting that family court â€œdoes not have jurisdiction or authority to apportion nonmarital propertyâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(4) (Supp. 2004) (stating that property excluded from the marital estate by written contract of the parties is considered nonmarital property).
In the instant case, the litigation between the parties was clearly marital in nature as the Wife sought a divorce, custody of the child, child support, alimony, and equitable distribution of the marital property.Â  Husband asserted the premarital agreement as a defense to the causes of action for alimony and equitable distribution.Â  The family court was then required to determine, pursuant to Hardee v. Hardee, 355 S.C. 382, 585 S.E.2d 501 (2003), whether the premarital agreement was valid and enforceable.
The family court, in the case sub judice, did not attempt to distribute nonmarital property or provide support in contravention of the agreement, as was sought by the husband in Gilley.Â  The determination of the enforceability of the agreement arose in the course of marital litigation and was within the family courtâ€™s jurisdiction under section 20-7-420(2).Â  Concomitantly, the family court was correct in applying the jurisdiction of the court.
II.Â  PREMARITAL AGREEMENT

Husband contends the trial court erred in finding the premarital agreement was invalid and unenforceable as a result of being unconscionable and signed under duress.
Premarital agreements, also called antenuptial or prenuptial agreements, are agreements between prospective spouses made in contemplation of marriage.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines a prenuptial agreement as â€œ[a]n agreement made before marriage usu[ally] to resolve issues of support and property division if the marriage ends in divorce or by the death of a spouse.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1220 (8th ed. 2004).Â  Antenuptial settlements are contracts or agreements entered into between a man and woman before marriage, but in contemplation and generally in consideration of marriage, whereby the property rights and interests of either the prospective husband or wife, or of both of them, are determined, or where property is secured to either or to both of them, or to their children.Â  41 C.J.S. Husband and Wife Â§ 61 (1991).
The consideration for a premarital agreement is the marriage itself.Â  Because such agreements are executory, they become effective only upon marriage.Â  See South Carolina Loan & Trust Co. v. Lawton, 69 S.C. 345, 48 S.E. 282 (1904).Â  In South Carolina Loan & Trust Co. v. Lawton, the Supreme Court explained:

  There is not complete execution of such instruments until actual marriage, and it does not matter how many changes may be made, and how many different instruments may be signed, the settlement, in the last form it assumes before marriage, is the real contract supported by the consideration of marriage.

Id. at 349, 48 S.E. at 283.
 In Stork v. First National Bank, 281 S.C. 515, 316 S.E.2d 400 (1984), the Supreme Court inculcated:

  Antenuptial agreements, which usually involve the wife-to-be giving up her right to dower in consideration of marriage, will be enforced if made voluntarily and in good faith and if fair and equitable.Â  Rieger v. Schaible, 81 Neb. 33, 115 N.W. 560 (1908) (citing Pierce v. Pierce, 71 N.Y. 154, 27 Am. Rep. 22).Â  Such contracts are not opposed to public policy but are highly beneficial to serving the best interest of the marriage relationship.

Id. at 516, 316 S.E.2d at 401.Â  An antenuptial contract is valid and will be upheld when, and only when, it is entered into freely, fairly, and in good faith by parties legally competent to contract.Â  41 C.J.S. Husband and Wife Â§ 62 (1991).Â  An antenuptial agreement must be free from duress, fraud, deceit, misrepresentation, or overreaching.Â  Id.Â  Further, the agreement must not be unconscionable.Â  Id.
The South Carolina Supreme Court, in Hardee v. Hardee, 355 S.C. 382, 585 S.E.2d 501 (2003), explicated:

  Recent case law of this Court supports Husbandâ€™s contention that parties are free to contractually alter the obligations which would otherwise attach to marriage.Â  In Stork v. First Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina, 281 S.C. 515, 516, 316 S.E.2d 400, 401 (1984), this Court held that antenuptial agreements â€œwill be enforced if made voluntarily and in good faith and if fair and equitable. . . . Such contracts are not opposed to public policy but are highly beneficial to serving the best interest of the marriage relationship.â€ 

Id. at 387, 585 S.E.2d at 503.Â  In determining whether a premarital agreement should be enforced, our supreme court professed:

  (1) Was the agreement obtained through fraud, duress, or mistake, or through misrepresentation or nondisclosure of material facts? (2) Is the agreement unconscionable? (3) Have the facts and circumstances changed since the agreement was executed, so as to make its enforcement unfair and unreasonable?

Id. at 389, 585 S.E.2d at 504 (internal quotations omitted).
A.Â  Duress

Husband avers the family court improperly concluded Wife signed the premarital agreement while under duress.Â  We disagree.
Duress is a condition of mind produced by improper external pressure or influence that practically destroys the free agency of a party and causes him to do an act or form a contract not of his own volition.Â  Cherry v. Shelby Mut. Plate Glass & Cas. Co., 191 S.C. 177, 4 S.E.2d 123 (1939); Cox & Floyd Grading, Inc. v. Kajima Constr. Servs., Inc., 356 S.C. 512, 589 S.E.2d 789 (Ct. App. 2003); Willms Trucking Co. v. JW Constr. Co., 314 S.C. 170, 442 S.E.2d 197 (Ct. App. 1994).
Corpus Juris Secundum defines duress:

  â€œDuressâ€ may be defined as subjecting a person to a pressure which overcomes his or her will and coerces him or her to comply with demands to which he or she would not yield if acting as a free agent.Â  Some definitions of â€œduressâ€ contain not only the element of pressure overcoming the victimâ€™s will but also the element that the pressure or compulsion consists of improper, wrongful, or unlawful conduct, acts, or threats.
  Further, â€œduressâ€ has been defined as the condition of mind produced by the wrongful conduct of another rendering a person incompetent to contract with the exercise of his or her free will power, or as the condition of mind produced by an improper external pressure destroying free agency so as to cause the victim to act or contract without use of his or her own volition, or as unlawful constraint whereby a person is forced to do some act against his or her will.

17A C.J.S. Contracts Â§ 175 (1999) (footnotes omitted).
The central question with respect to whether a contract was executed under duress is whether, considering all the surrounding circumstances, one party to the transaction was prevented from exercising his free will by threats or the wrongful conduct of another.Â  17A Am. Jur. 2d Contracts Â§ 218 (2004).Â  Freedom of will is essential to the validity of an agreement.Â  Id.Â  A party claiming â€œduressâ€ can prevail if he shows that he has been the victim of a wrongful or unlawful act or threat of a kind that deprives the victim of unfettered will, with the result that he was compelled to make a disproportionate exchange of values.Â  Id.
In order to establish that a contract was procured through duress, three things must be proved: (1) coercion; (2) putting a person in such fear that he is bereft of the quality of mind essential to the making of a contract; and (3) that the contract was thereby obtained as a result of this state of mind.Â  In re Nightingaleâ€™s Estate, 182 S.C. 527, 189 S.E. 890 (1937).Â  The fear which makes it impossible for a person to exercise his own free will is not so much to be tested by the means employed to accomplish the act, as by the state of mind produced by the means invoked.Â  Id.; Willms Trucking Co., 314 S.C. at 179, 442 S.E.2d at 202.Â  If one of the parties to an agreement is in a position to dictate its terms to such an extent as to substitute his will for the will of the other party thereto, it is not a mutual, voluntary agreement, but becomes an agreement emanating entirely from his own mind.Â  In re Nightingaleâ€™s Estate, 182 S.C. at 547, 189 S.E at 898; Willms Trucking Co., 314 S.C. at 179, 442 S.E.2d at 202.Â  If a partyâ€™s manifestation of assent is induced by an improper threat by the other party that leaves the victim no reasonable alternative, the contract is voidable by the victim.Â  Willms Trucking Co., 314 S.C. at 179, 442 S.E.2d at 202.Â  Whether or not duress exists in a particular case is a question of fact to be determined according to the circumstances of each case, such as the age, sex, and capacity of the party influenced.Â  Id.; see also Santee Portland Cement Corp. v. Mid-State Redi-Mix Concrete Co., 273 S.C. 784, 260 S.E.2d 178 (1979) (stating whether or not duress was present is a question ordinarily determined on a case by case basis).
Duress is viewed with a subjective test which looks at the individual characteristics of the person allegedly influenced, and duress does not occur if the victim has a reasonable alternative to succumbing and fails to take advantage of it.Â  Blejski v. Blejski, 325 S.C. 491, 480 S.E.2d 462 (Ct. App. 1997) (citing Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 175 cmt. b & c (1981)).Â  Duress is a defense to an otherwise valid contract.Â  17A Am. Jur. 2d Contracts Â§ 218.Â  Duress renders a contract voidable at the option of the oppressed party.Â  Santee Portland Cement Corp., 273 S.C. at 784, 260 S.E.2d at 178.
Assumptively concluding Wife was allowed the opportunity to view the premarital agreement three months in advance, the evidence in the record indicates: (1) Wife did not understand the contents of the agreement; (2) she did not freely enter into the agreement; (3) she attempted to translate the agreement into Russian in order to better comprehend the document; (4) she became frustrated as she was unable to complete a satisfactory translation; and (5) her notes indicate there are several words for which she could not find a translation, including â€œundivided,â€ â€œequitable,â€ and â€œpro rata.â€Â  Consequently, Wife could not understand the agreement.
Additionally, Husband was aware of the deadline with respect to Wifeâ€™s visa.Â  According to his own testimony, Husband made it perfectly clear to Wife that she must sign the agreement if she wanted to be married prior to the expiration of her visa.Â  Wife was in the United States with no means to support herself.Â  She relied solely and completely on Husband for support.Â  Wife had no money of her own with which to retain and consult an attorney or a translator.Â  Whether a party obtained independent legal advice is a significant consideration in evaluating whether an antenuptial agreement was voluntarily and understandingly made.Â  See 41 C.J.S. Husband and Wife Â§ 62 (1991).Â Â Â  The family court found if Wife was not able to marry, then she would be forced to return to Ukraine.Â  Because she was pregnant with Husbandâ€™s child, she sought to insure his continued support and to remain in the United States.
Wife did not enter into the agreement freely and voluntarily.Â  Ample evidence exists to support the family courtâ€™s determination that Wife, given the circumstances she faced, signed the agreement under duress and without a clear understanding of what she was signing.Â  The family court did not err in finding Wife signed the agreement under duress.
B.Â  Unconscionability

Husband asseverates the trial court erred in finding the agreement was unconscionable and, therefore, unenforceable.Â  We disagree.
Unconscionability is the absence of meaningful choice on the part of one party due to one-sided contract provisions, together with terms which are so oppressive that no reasonable person would make them and no fair and honest person would accept them.Â  Carolina Care Plan, Inc. v. United HealthCare Servs., Inc., 361 S.C. 544, 606 S.E.2d 752 (2004); Hardee v. Hardee, 355 S.C. 382, 585 S.E.2d 501 (2003); Fanning v. Fritzâ€™s Pontiac-Cadillac-Buick, Inc., 322 S.C. 399, 472 S.E.2d 242 (1996); see also 17 C.J.S. Contracts Â§ 4 (1999) (noting some courts state that a party seeking to show an agreement is unconscionable must show that, at the time the agreement was formed, there was an absence of meaningful choice and the contract terms unreasonably favor one party).
â€œIn determining unconscionability, courts are limited to considering facts and circumstances existing when the contract was executed.â€Â  Hardee v. Hardee, 348 S.C. 84, 95-96, 558 S.E.2d 264, 269-70 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 208 (1981)), affâ€™d as modified, 355 S.C. 382, 585 S.E.2d 501 (2003); see also Lackey v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 330 S.C. 388, 397, 498 S.E.2d 898, 903 (Ct. App. 1998)(â€œIf the court finds that a contract clause was unconscionable at the time it was made, the court may refuse to enforce the contract clause or limit the application of the unconscionable clause to avoid any unconscionable result.â€).Â  â€œA determination whether a contract is unconscionable depends upon all the facts and circumstances of a particular case.â€Â  17A Am. Jur. 2d Contracts Â§ 279 (2004); see also 17 C.J.S. Contracts Â§ 4 (1999) (â€œThe determination of unconscionability is fact specific, and the totality of the circumstances must be assessed.â€).
In order to determine whether the agreement was unconscionable, we examine its terms and their application to the parties.Â  The agreement provided in part that both parties would be responsible for paying rent as well as real estate taxes and utilities on a property owned by Husbandâ€™s mother and leased to Husband.Â  The agreement required Husband â€œshall have a proportionate interest in the increase in value during the marriage of the homestead real estate, proportionate to the percentage contribution of the household expenses, if any, and child care/household duties performed by William Holler during the course of the marriage.â€Â  The agreement did not contain a similar provision regarding Wifeâ€™s interest as a result of her contributions of childcare or household duties.

  Profoundly, the agreement stated:Â  
  10.Â  Support.Â  Each of the parties has income from property interest sufficient to provide for his or her respective support.Â  Each has been self-supporting for a period of time prior to the contemplated marriage.Â  Both parties feel that they are capable of future self-support and of maintaining themselves on a self-supporting basis.

However, at the time the agreement was signed, Husband was providing all of Wifeâ€™s support and knew Wife had to return to Ukraine unless she obtained independent subsidy.
Significantly, the exhibit listing the partiesâ€™ respective financial information reveals Husband had a net worth over $150,000 with $30,000 in annual income, while Wife had $0.00 listed beside each category of assets as well as $0.00 for her net worth.Â  The declaration indicated she earned $1,400.00 per year as a music teacher in Ukraine.Â  Apodictically, we find ample evidence in the record demonstrating the premarital agreement was unconscionable and, therefore, unenforceable.
CONCLUSION

The family court possessed jurisdiction to determine whether the premarital agreement was valid and enforceable.Â  Further, the family court did not err in finding: (1) Wife signed the agreement under duress; and (2) the agreement was unconscionable and unenforceable.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Wife is referred to in the record as both Nataliya and Natasha.

description: We affirm the trial court's decision affirming the Beaufort City Council's revocation of Walter Gay's business license to conduct tours in the historic district of Beaufort based on a city ordinance prohibiting "theme vehicles" from touring the historic district.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
    
    In The Court of Appeals
    
    


  


  
    
      
        Walter L. Gay, d/b/a Sandlapper Tours, Appellant,
        
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        The City of Beaufort, Respondent.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3980
Submitted March1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Walter L. Gay, of St. Helena, Pro Se, for Appellant.
        William B. Harvey, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: This is an appeal from the trial courtâ€™s decision affirming the Beaufort City Councilâ€™s revocation of Walter Gayâ€™s business license to conduct tours in the historic district of Beaufort.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS

On August 5, 2002, the City of Beaufort granted Walter Gay, doing business as Sandlapper Trolleys, a business license for the purposes of conducting tours through Beaufort, including the historic district.Â  Within the next few days, the city told Gay the license would be revoked because his tour vehicle was considered a â€œtrolleyâ€ under Beaufort City Ordinance section 7-11002 and, therefore, could not be used in the historic district.Â  
Gay wrote a letter to the city manager requesting that the city council reconsider revoking his license.Â  Alternatively, he asked that the city ordinance prohibiting the use of trolleys in the historic district be changed.Â  The city council referred the matter to the city manager and city attorney and further requested Beaufortâ€™s Tourist Management Advisory Commission (â€œCommissionâ€) to review the ordinance and give a recommendation.Â  
In 2003, based on the Commissionâ€™s recommendation that the vehicle was considered a â€œtrolleyâ€ for purposes of the ordinance as well as statements by several of the individuals who created the ordinance, the city council voted to revoke Gayâ€™s license.Â  Gay appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the decision of the city council.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW

Where the city council of a municipality has acted after considering all of the facts, the court should not disturb the finding unless such action is arbitrary, unreasonable, or an obvious abuse of its discretion.Â  Bob Jones Univ., Inc. v. City of Greenville, 243 S.C. 351, 360, 133 S.E.2d 843, 847 (1963).Â  This court will not disturb on appeal such findings of the city council, concurred in by a circuit judge, unless they are without evidentiary support or against the clear preponderance of the evidence.Â  Id. at 363, 133 S.E.2d at 848 (referring specifically to the findings of a master-in-equity, which affirmed the actions of a city council).Â  

  LAW/ANALYSIS
  Gay claims the trial court erred in affirming Beaufort City Councilâ€™s decision to revoke his license to conduct tours through the historic district because his tour vehicle is not a â€œtheme vehicle,â€ as defined by the city ordinance.Â  We disagree.

The City of Beaufort Ordinance Â§ 7-11003 provides that â€œ[t]heme vehicles other than horse-drawn carriages . . . may not be utilized for touring purposes in the historic district.â€Â  The ordinances further define â€œtheme vehicleâ€ in the following manner:

  A vehicle whose design, shape, form, color, signage, or accoutrements is intended to create a particular identity and to call special attention to that vehicle, such as a horse-drawn carriage, trolley, pedicab, snail vehicle, or articulated vehicle.Â  Touring vehicles displaying commercial or institutional identification in a customary fashion shall not be considered theme vehicles.Â  

Ordinance Â§ 7-11002. (Emphasis added.)Â Â  
Gay considered his tour vehicle a â€œtrolley,â€ as evidenced by his trade name â€œSandlapper Trolleysâ€ and the content of his letter to the city manager.Â  In that letter Gay referred to his tour vehicle as a â€œtrolleyâ€ numerous times.Â  For example, he stated, â€œI admit that what I have looks similar to a trolley and it is called a trolley.â€Â  He also argued that his â€œtrolley is a clean vehicleâ€ and â€œis an asset to any historic area.â€Â  He also requested help from the city manager in â€œfinding a way to utilize [his] trolley in the historic tours of Beaufort.â€Â  Finally, he asked the city council to consider amending the ordinance so his vehicle could be used in the historic district.Â  
Additionally, the city manager and the city attorney determined, based on their evaluation of the tour vehicle and the ordinance, that the tour vehicle was a â€œtheme vehicleâ€ as defined by the city ordinance.Â  â€œ[B]ecause of the design and shapeâ€ of the tour vehicle, the Commission concluded that the tour vehicle was a trolley and, therefore, fit within Beaufortâ€™s definition of a theme vehicle.[2]Â  At the city council meeting, a representative of the Commission stated, â€œan ordinance change would be necessary for [Gay] to operateâ€ his tour vehicle in the historic district.Â  
Lastly, the city council agreed that the tour vehicle was a bus.Â  However, â€œbecause of its design it is considered a theme vehicle.â€Â  Therefore, the findings of the Beaufort City Council, concurred with by the circuit court, are supported by the preponderance of the evidence.Â Â  
For the reasons stated herein, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Any references to the Commissionâ€™s recommendations or city councilâ€™s decisions were extracted from the Beaufort City Council meeting minutes.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Jane Doe, Claimant, Respondent, 
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        S.C. Department of Disabilities and Special Needs, Employer, and State Accident Fund, Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â Â  3981
  Heard March 9, 2005 â€“ Filed April 18, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Cynthia B. Polk and Thomas McRoy Shelley, III, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Edward L. Graham, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: The South Carolina Department of Disabilities and Special Needs (Department) and the State Accident Fund appeal the decision of the circuit court reversing the findings of the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Full Commission) and awarding benefits to Jane Doe (Claimant) based on her mental injuries.Â  We reverse.
FACTS

Claimant worked for the Department as a licensed practical nurse (LPN) for approximately eighteen years.Â  She cared for individuals suffering from extreme mental retardation and cognitive disabilities such that they require institutional care.Â  As an LPN, Claimant was responsible for the daily medical care of the patients in her unit.Â  
In early 1997, the Department moved the individuals under Claimantâ€™s care into group homes because they were â€œhigher functioning.â€Â  As a result, patients who required more medical attention were moved into the unit where Claimant worked.Â  Some of the new patients were more aggressive than Claimantâ€™s prior patients.Â  
Claimant was injured in June of 1997 when a patient kicked her in the abdomen.Â  She sought medical attention and was prescribed anti-inflammatory and pain medication.Â  When she returned to her doctor, Dr. Paschal, for her recheck in August 1997, she complained about being depressed and having â€œa lot of crying spells.â€Â  She was diagnosed with depression and prescribed Prozac.Â  She returned to Dr. Paschal several times for her depression and was prescribed Serzone.Â  Beginning August 17, 1997, Claimant took a leave of absence from the Department as a result of her stress.Â  
Claimant returned to work full-time in February 1998.Â  Shortly thereafter, a patient pushed a cart into her, causing Claimant to sprain her left arm and knee.Â  She was placed in a sling and knee immobilizer and given an anti-inflammatory and pain medication.Â  
Claimant continued to see her doctors regarding her depression.Â  Each time, she related her depression to the stress and environment at work.Â  In August 1998, she accepted termination under a workforce reduction program.
After leaving the Department, Claimant continued to have severe depression, eating disorders, and other mental problems requiring both outpatient treatment and hospitalization.Â  Throughout her treatment, Claimant complained of being depressed, not being able to sleep, and other psychological problems. 
Claimant filed a Form 50, seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits for the two physical injuries she sustained in June 1997 and February 1998.Â  Additionally, she sought benefits for mental injury.Â  Specifically, she alleged:Â  â€œThe unusual and extraordinary work conditions and/or the two physical injuries caused the Claimant to suffer disabling mental injury.â€ Â The two physical injuries were admitted by the Department, and Claimant was paid seventy-eight dollars for her expenses.Â  The Department denied the mental injury claims.
At the hearing, Claimant presented evidence of the change in the work environment at the Department beginning in the spring of 1997.Â  She discussed her increased responsibilities and her increased exposure to aggressive patients.Â  Testimony by other employees of the Department confirmed the work conditions.
Claimant indicated the physical injuries for which she sought compensation were but some of the physical assaults which occurred while working for the Department after the change in patients.Â  Among other things, she testified she had feces smeared in her face by a patient.Â  Claimant testified she was stressed and was very afraid of receiving further physical injuries.Â  Testimony indicated that she could not transfer to another area of the Department because no other employees were willing to accept her shift. 
The Department produced evidence that the change of patients was not an unexpected or unusual event.Â  Additionally, the Department showed the number of patients under Claimantâ€™s care decreased as a result of the change.Â  The evidence indicated Claimant was specifically trained to handle more aggressive patients, and it was not unusual for nurses who worked for the Department to be subjected to aggressive behavior. 
The single commissioner found Claimant had failed to prove her mental injury was the result of unusual or extraordinary circumstances.Â  He found the environment was one to be expected when dealing with the patients in the care of the Department.Â  Additionally, the commissioner found no evidence that Claimantâ€™s physical injuries directly caused her stress and fears.Â  Therefore, the commissioner found Claimant had failed to provide evidence that her mental injury was compensable.Â  The Full Commission agreed and adopted the findings and conclusions of the single commissioner.Â  
The circuit court reversed the order of the Full Commission.Â  The circuit court found Claimant had presented substantial evidence of the unusual and extraordinary nature of her work environment.Â  Additionally, the circuit court found the mental injury was accompanied by the physical injuries, and therefore the circuit court did not need to determine whether the work conditions were unusual and extraordinary.Â  The circuit court specifically noted that physical injuries do not have to be the direct cause of the mental injury, but must be a cause and must accompany the mental injury.Â  Finally, the circuit court awarded Claimant five hundred weeks of total and permanent disability compensation in the amount of $330.86 per week for her mental injury.Â  This appeal followed.
ISSUES ON APPEAL


  I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the circuit court err by reversing the decision of the Full Commission and finding Claimantâ€™s mental injury was compensable as the result of unusual and extraordinary work conditions?
  
  II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the circuit court err by reversing the decision of the Full Commission and finding Claimantâ€™s mental injury was compensable as the result of a mental injury accompanied by a physical injury?
  III.Â Â Â Â  Did the circuit court err by awarding Claimant total and permanent disability benefits instead of remanding for a determination by the Full Commission?

STANDARD OF REVIEW

The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Full Commission.â€Â  Id. In an appeal from the commission, this court, as well as the circuit court, may not substitute its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2004).Â  The appellate court can reverse or modify the Full Commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â Id.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Mental-Mental
The Department contends the circuit court erred in reversing the determination by the Full Commission that Claimantâ€™s mental disability was not caused by â€œextraordinary and unusualâ€ conditions in her employment.Â  We agree.
A mental-mental injury is a purely mental injury resulting from emotional stimuli.Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  According to section 42-1-160 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004):

  Stress arising out of and in the course of employment unaccompanied by physical injury and resulting in mental illness or injury is not a personal injury unless it is established that the stressful employment conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary and unusual in comparison to the normal conditions of the employment.

The requirement of â€œunusual or extraordinary conditions in employmentâ€ for a claimant to recover for a mental-mental injury refers to conditions to the particular job in which the injury occurs, not to conditions of employment in general.Â  Shealy, 341 at 456, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  In order to recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits, Claimant must prove both:Â  (1) that she was exposed to unusual and extraordinary conditions in her employment; and (2) that these unusual and extraordinary conditions were the proximate cause of her mental breakdown.Â  Id. at 459, 535 S.E.2d at 444.
As the finder of fact, the Full Commission found the conditions of Claimantâ€™s employment were not extraordinary or unusual for her particular job.Â  The Full Commission specifically found the movement of patients between facilities was not extraordinary, and the change in the level of care that Claimant had to provide her patients was not an extraordinary or unusual condition.Â  The Full Commission found that being â€œsubjected to aggressive behavior by mentally-challenged patients is not an extraordinary and unusual condition of employment as a nurse at [the Department], as this occurs with some frequency and is the subject of specific training for [Department] employees.â€Â  Finally, the Full Commission found:Â  

  Based upon her work history and training, it was not unexpected that Claimant would be subjected to changes in the amount of medical care her patients required, that she would be subjected to loud and aggressive behavior by patients, that she would fear loud and aggressive behavior by patients, and that she would suffer minor physical injuries as a result of aggressive behavior by patients. 

The findings of fact made by the Full Commission are supported by substantial evidence in the record.[1]Â  Tenia Rae Allen, a supervisor of first shift nurses, testified that dealing with aggressive people was not an unusual situation and that nurses were injured even before the more aggressive patients came to Claimantâ€™s unit. Â A co-worker, Kim Willis, provided additional testimony to indicate the working conditions were not unusual.Â  She stated: â€œThere have always been times when we would have certain patients that were harder to deal with . . . . Most of the ones we have now have more medical needs, but there have always been times when it was hard to deal with, the whole 21 years Iâ€™ve been there.â€ Â Willis also testified that as a nurse she expected changes in the types of patients she would be dealing with and felt it could get even worse than it was at the time Claimant left.Â  Finally, she testified that some physical confrontation with the patients is to be expected and that was why they had classes to train and â€œlearn how to deal with that.â€ 
In addition to finding the condition of Claimantâ€™s work environment was not extraordinary and unusual, the Full Commission found she had prior and current non-work related stressors, which could impact her mental injury.Â  The Full Commission found her hospitalizations for depression that occurred prior to her employment with the Department contributed to her current bout with depression.Â  Additionally, at the time she was incurring the changes at work, she was also coping with her fatherâ€™s diagnosis of cancer and his subsequent death from the disease. Â Dr. Paschal and Dr. Lowe document these additional factors in the medical notes.
 While the circuit court did a good job of detailing the evidence contrary to the findings of the Full Commission, it appears to have ignored the substantial evidence supporting the Full Commissionâ€™s findings.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court erred in making its own findings of fact and in reversing the decision of the Full Commission as it relates to Claimantâ€™s mental-mental claim.
II.Â Â Â Â  Physical-Mental
The Department next contends the circuit court erred in reversing the Full Commissionâ€™s finding that Claimantâ€™s mental claims were not caused by her physical injuries and, therefore, not compensable.Â  We agree.
Both mental-mental injuries, in which the injury is brought on by the extraordinary and unusual conditions of the claimantâ€™s work, and physical-mental injuries, in which a physical injury induced the mental disability, are compensable.Â  See Getsinger v. Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corp., 335 S.C. 77, 80-81, 515 S.E.2d 104, 105-06 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œWhere . . . the mental injury is induced by physical injury, it is not necessary that it result from unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment.â€Â  Estridge v. Joslyn Clark Controls, Inc., 325 S.C. 532, 538, 482 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  A condition, which is induced by a physical injury, is thereby causally related to that injury.Â  Id. (defining cause as that which produces an effect); Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, 221 (6th ed. 1990) (defining cause as â€œto make to induce. . . .â€)).Â  â€œ[The mental injury] is a new symptom manifesting from the same harm to the body.â€Â  Estridge, 325 at 538-39, 482 S.E.2d at 581.
Despite the circuit courtâ€™s finding that a physical injury need not be the direct cause of a mental injury, nothing in section 42-1-160, which explains that certain mental injuries are compensable, removes the causation requirement from a physical-mental claim.Â  Because there is no declaration in the statute altering the requirements for a physical-mental claim, the physical injury must still â€œinduceâ€ or â€œcauseâ€ the mental injury for the mental injury to be compensable.Â  See Caughman v. Columbia Y.M.C.A., 212 S.C. 337, 344, 47 S.E.2d 788, 791 (1948) (â€œIt must be assumed that the Legislature was aware of the policy established by [decisions of the courts] when the legislation under consideration was enacted, and it is reasonable to suppose that if it was intended to change such policy, the Legislature would have expressly so declared . . . .â€). 
In the case before us, there is substantial evidence in the record supporting the Full Commissionâ€™s determination that the mental injury was not induced or caused by the minor physical injuries Claimant sustained.Â  Claimant stated her fear, the change in work conditions, the loud noises, and the increased stress resulted in her mental injuries.Â  The doctorsâ€™ records indicate Claimantâ€™s issues were related to the stressors of her work and to her fear of assaults.Â  Although Claimant feared assaults by patients, nothing in the record indicates this fear was directly caused by the injuries she suffered to her abdomen, knee, and arm.Â  Furthermore, there was substantial evidence suggesting that other stressors in Claimantâ€™s life that were unrelated to work caused her mental injuries.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court erred in reversing the decision of the Full Commission.Â 
CONCLUSION
We find there was substantial evidence to support the Full Commissionâ€™s findings that Claimantâ€™s mental claims did not result from extraordinary and unusual conditions of her employment.Â  We hold any claim based upon a physical-mental injury must demonstrate that the physical injury caused or induced the mental injury and not that the mental injury was only temporally related.Â  Therefore, we find there is substantial evidence to support the Full Commissionâ€™s finding that her mental injury was not caused by the minor physical injuries she sustained.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is 
REVERSED.[2]
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We disagree with Claimantâ€™s argument that her mental injury was caused by an unlawful work environment.Â  In support of this argument, Claimant points out that the Department did not abide by Department of Health and Environmental Control regulations.Â  However, these regulations deal with contractual conditions the Department must meet to receive money from the federal government.Â  See 42 CFR Â§ 483.430(d)(1) & Â§ 483.470(a)(1) (1997). While not following the regulations might result in the Departmentâ€™s loss of federal funding, violating the regulations does not create an â€œunlawfulâ€ work environment. 
[2] Because we find the decision of the circuit court should be reversed and the decision of the Full Commission reinstated, we need not address the Departmentâ€™s remaining issue that the circuit court erred in making findings of fact related to the nature of Claimantâ€™s disability and amount of compensation due Claimant.

description: The LoPrestis appeal the grant of summary judgment to John Burry and the Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation District in their lawsuit arising from their purchase of a home encumbered by a flood easement.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John N. LoPresti and Janice LoPresti, Appellants,
v.
John Burry, Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation District of Fountain Inn, South Carolina, Everette H. Babb, Frederick E.
Landrith, Landrith Surveying, Inc., and Greenville County, Defendants,
Of Whom John Burry and Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation District of Fountain Inn, South Carolina are, Respondents
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3982
Heard March 10, 2005 â€“ Filed April 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael Stephen Chambers, of Greenville, for Appellants.
Christopher R. Antley, John Robert Devlin, Jr. and W. Francis Marion, Jr., all of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  John and Janice LoPresti appeal the grant of summary judgment to John Burry and the Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation District of Fountain Inn in their lawsuit arising from their purchase of a home encumbered by a flood easement.Â  We affirm. 
In the summer of 1976, Burry bought 172 acres of land, known as tract 34, in Greenville and Laurens counties.Â  Several months later, in conjunction with a federal flood control project, Rabon Creek requested and received an easement from Burry for the construction of a dam on tract 34 and the impoundment of water to create Lake Beulah.Â  Rabon Creek recorded the easement in both Greenville and Laurens counties. 
In 1986, after the construction of the dam and lake, Burry subdivided the remaining property into lots, which he later sold to various individuals.Â  As part of the process of preparing the lots for sale, Burry hired surveyor T.H. Walker to prepare a subdivision survey plat of the property, instructing him to survey and plat lots approximately one acre in size next to the lake.Â  
After conducting the field surveys, Walker presented Burry with a plat that contained a dotted line labeled â€œFlood Planeâ€ [sic] that ran across the numbered lots abutting the lake.Â  The line represented the elevation of the spillway of the dam to be 718.5 feet.Â  At Burryâ€™s instructions, Walker removed the line, and Burry recorded the altered plat without the â€œflood planeâ€ line.Â  
In 1990, Burry conveyed lot 12, one of the lakefront lots, to William V. and Tammy M. Easterday.Â  The Easterdays constructed a home on the lot and located it within Rabon Creekâ€™s easement.Â  In 1993, the Easterdays conveyed the home and lot to Marion Harrison.Â  In 1994, the Harrisons conveyed the property to the LoPrestis.
It appears undisputed that, before and during the LoPrestisâ€™ purchase of their home, Rabon Creek did not actually perform the inspections required by an â€œOperation and Maintenance Agreementâ€ that it entered into with the United States Department of Agriculture.Â  Specifically, the agreement required Rabon Creek to â€œprohibit the installation of any structure or facilities that will interfere with the operation or maintenance of the project measures.â€Â  The inspections were actually performed by the Department of Agriculture.Â  Moreover, although construction on the LoPrestisâ€™ home began in 1991, the inspection reports did not acknowledge this fact until 1994, when notations began to appear in the reports about houses located in the floodplain area.Â  Even then, Rabon Creek took no action regarding this development. 
Unusually heavy rainfall during January 1995 caused the lake to flood the LoPrestisâ€™ finished basement to a height of about fourteen inches.Â  In August 1995, the remnants of Hurricane Jerry caused the lake level within the flood easement to rise and flood the Loprestisâ€™ home, completely engulfing their basement and coming to within four inches of the finished elevation of the second floor above the basement. 
In 1996, the LoPrestis brought this action against Burry, Rabon Creek, and other defendants alleging various causes of action arising out of the damage to their property.Â  The LoPrestisâ€™ lawsuit was later consolidated with three other similar cases.
